screens.headline: Control $10,000 of stock for just $200?
screens.text: Last month, NVDA moved 10%. Stock investors made $1,000. Options traders made $4,000. Same stock, same move, but 4x the returns. This is leverage - and it's not as scary as it sounds.

screens.headline: What exactly is an option?
screens.text: An option is a CONTRACT that gives you the right (not obligation) to buy or sell 100 shares of stock at a specific price, by a specific date. Think of it as a coupon with an expiration date - you can use it or let it expire.

screens.headline: Think of it like a house deposit
screens.text: You want to buy a $400,000 house, but you're not sure yet. You put down a $5,000 deposit to lock in that price for 90 days. During those 90 days...

reveal_sections.label: House value rises to $450,000
reveal_sections.content: You exercise your right to buy at $400,000. You just made $50,000 (minus your $5,000 deposit).

reveal_sections.label: House value drops to $350,000
reveal_sections.content: You walk away. You lose your $5,000 deposit, but you didn't buy an overpriced house. Smart move.

reveal_sections.label: This is exactly how options work
reveal_sections.content: The deposit = premium. The locked-in price = strike price. The 90 days = expiration date.

cards.definition: The price you pay for the option contract
The price you can buy/sell the stock at
cards.example: $150 strike means you can buy at $150, even if stock is at $200
Jan 19, 2024 = your last day to use it or lose it

screens.question: What's the main difference between buying stock vs buying an option?
options: Options have an expiration date, stocks don't
Options can only go up in value
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Stocks you can hold forever. Options EXPIRE - they have a countdown clock. This is crucial to understand because time decay will become your friend or enemy depending on your strategy.
screens.explanation_wrong: Not quite. The key difference is TIME. Stocks = no expiration. Options = they expire worthless if you don't use them. This is why options can decay in value even if the stock doesn't move.

screens.question: You buy 1 option contract. How many shares of stock does this control?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! This is critical: 1 option contract = 100 shares. So if you see a premium of $2.50, you're actually paying $250 (Ã—100). This trips up beginners constantly.
screens.explanation_wrong: Not quite - and this is a CRITICAL detail: 1 option contract always represents 100 shares. So a $2 premium actually costs you $200. Many beginners miss this and get surprised by their actual cost!

screens.question: Stock is at $100. You can either: A) Buy 100 shares for $10,000, or B) Buy 1 call option for $500. Which has more risk?
options: Buying stock - you could lose all $10,000
Buying the option - you could lose all $500
screens.explanation_correct: Right! With options, your max loss is ALWAYS just the premium you paid ($500). With stock, you could theoretically lose all $10,000 if the company goes bankrupt. This defined risk is why many traders prefer options.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about max loss. Stock: you own $10,000 worth - it could go to zero (bankruptcy). Option: you paid $500 - that's the MOST you can lose. Options actually have LESS dollar risk in this case.

cards.back: A CONTRACT giving you the RIGHT (not obligation) to buy/sell 100 shares at a set price by a set date. You pay a premium upfront.

cards.front: Why use options instead of stock?
cards.back: Leverage: Control $10,000 of stock for just $500. Defined risk: Max loss = premium paid. Flexibility: Profit when stock goes up, down, or sideways.
Options EXPIRE. If you're wrong about timing, you can lose 100% of premium paid. Stock you can hold forever and wait for recovery.

screens.celebration_message: Great start! You just learned why millions of traders use options. Next up: the two types of options you can trade.
